question: Mm. Muriel.
answer: Mm?

question: Coffee.
answer: Thank you, dear. Looking for something, dear?

question: My socks.
answer: Why don't you look in your sock drawer?

question: That's where I found my underwear.
answer: Oh. Well, try your underwear drawer.

question: I'm in my underwear drawer.
answer: Well, they must be somewhere. Socks just don't get up and walk away by themselves.

question: Muriel, I thought the top two-and-a- half drawers were to be mine! I wish you'd tell Gussie --
answer: The closet! That's where they are. We put them in the closet.

question: Socks? In the closet?
answer: Well, there didn't seem to be any room in the drawers...

question: And there's so much of it in the closet!
answer: ...so Gussie and I decided that from now on we'll keep them in a basket on the shelf.

question: Well, thanks a lot!
answer: Jim, I do wish you'd make an effort to be a little less clumsy.

question: 'Morning, dear. Jim - He stands in front of the washstand lathering his face. Over scene we hear Muriel's voice from the shower. She is singing a lusty chorus of "Home On The Range." Jim picks up his razor and turns to the mirror. He reacts with annoyance, as he discovers it is covered with steam. With weary resignation he takes a towel and starts to rub off the mirror. As he clears one section another clouds up. By the time he gets it all reasonably clear he finds that his lather needs freshening. He grimly relathers his face only to find that the mirror is again clouded up. As he turns with exasperation toward the shower we see Muriel turn off the water, reach for a towel, start to dry herself.
answer: Excuse...

question: Excuse... If you don't mind, dear.
answer: Sorry. Moment, dear.

question: Take your time. I can spare the blood.
answer: Oh... cut yourself?

question: I cut myself every morning. I kind of look forward to it.
answer: Why don't you get an electric razor?

question: Don't like them. No close shave.
answer: Ridiculous! Bill Cole's been using one for years.

question: He doesn't have my beard!
answer: That's silly. Bill's beard is just as tough and coarse and --

question: I'm not interested in discussing the grain and texture of Bill Cole's hair follicles before I've had my orange juice.
answer: You don't have to carry on so. I only said, why don't you get an electric razor?

question: Because I prefer the cool, clean sweep of the tempered steel as it glides smoothly --
answer: Stop writing advertising copy! Hurry up, dear, you'll be late for breakfast.

question: ...Who did this?
answer: I did.

question: I have repeatedly told you -- -- don't cut up the morning paper until I've had a chance to look at it!
answer: I'm sorry, father. It's necessary research.

question: I suppose this is another of Miss Stellwagon's so-called Progressive Projects?
answer: Now dear, there just isn't any point in sending your children to an expensive school if you're going to undermine the teacher's authority in your own dining room.

question: I'm not undermining anything. I happen to be in the advertising business and keeping abreast of the times is important to me.
answer: And so is your children's education.

question: That's not the point.
answer: It certainly is.

question: All right. All right. I'll listen.
answer: It's just twenty-four words. But in simple eloquence it mirrors a minor tragedy of our times.

question: Well?...
answer: "Forced to sell. Farm dwelling, oak grove, apple orchard, trout stream, hay fields, four barns, seclusion, superb view, original beams, paved highway, acreage... Will sacrifice..."

question: Go on.
answer: That's all.

question: That's all?!
answer: You don't see it, do you, father?

question: Oh, indeed... crass commercialism... advertising...
answer: Miss Stellwagon says advertising is a basically parasitic profession.

question: Oh, she does?
answer: Miss Stellwagon says that advertising makes people who can't afford it buy things they don't want with money they haven't got.

question: Hello. Who? Miss Blandings, there's a Mr. Funkhauser wants to see you.
answer: Funkhauser? Oh, Mr. Funkhauser!

question: That's what he says.
answer: Uh -- better ask him to come up.

question: Says to come up.
answer: Oh -- uh -- darling, Mr. Funkhauser's here.

question: Oh -- uh -- darling, Mr. Funkhauser's here.
answer: ...Who?

question: You remember, Bunny Funkhauser, that clever young interior decorator we met at the Collins' cocktail party?
answer: What's he doing here?

question: Well, I imagine he's brought the -- uh -- estimates.
answer: ...Estimates?

question: Darling, you know how long we've said we've got to do something about this apartment, and, well, he called last week, and I had him come over, and he's got some simply wonderful ideas!
answer: There couldn't be two Bunny Funkhausers, could there?

question: Why, no, dear.
answer: Then this is the same clever young man who's responsible for that zebra- striped monstrosity in the Collins' living room?

question: That couch is terribly functional.
answer: Phil Collins told me what he paid for all that function! If you think I'm going to --

question: Red, yellow and green?!
answer: Oh, come, Mr. Blandings, let's not run away from color.

question: Not running away -- -- just backing off a little.
answer: Uh -- yes. Now as I see our room, it's definitely Colonial. You know, cobbler's bench, breakfront, pie cooler, student lamp, hooked rug. But everything in good taste. It must not jump out at you and scream

question: Heaven forbid.
answer: Of course, these things take imagination. You've simply got to be able to visualize.

question: If you'll forgive me, Mr. Funkhauser, what I'd like to visualize -- at this dreary hour -- is how much is this all going to cost?
answer: Well, really, I hesitate to say. After all -- -- by the time this wall is out we may find --

question: This wall is -- what?
answer: Out. Source of light is from the east. Obviously if our room is to have any function at all --

question: Visualize three feet of leaded panes, the rest --
answer: Can you give me a figure?

question: Well! Costs aren't what they used to be, you know, and --
answer: Just a figure.

question: Materials are impossible, labor has just run wild --
answer: Just an overall figure.

question: Well!... I shouldn't like to be tied down. But I suppose if you must have a figure, I'd say -- mm -- -- somewhere in the neighborhood of seven.
answer: Mm... Seven.

question: Mm.
answer: That would be seven... thousand?

question: Mm.
answer: We-ll. That seems fair. After all, we're not running away from color -- -- and we are tearing out walls -- Mr. Funkhauser, do you have a card?

question: We will, dear.
answer: Well, really, I --

question: We'll talk it all out and then we'll get in touch with Bunny.
answer: Well, really, I mean, I was under the impression we'd come to some decision today.

question: I'm sure we will.
answer: We-ll!

question: So nice of you to come. Good day.
answer: Now darling, you -- you just don't go to a man like Funkhauser and ask how much it's going to cost before you even know what he's going to do!

question: No, that would be too logical! Seven thousand dollars! Blueberry pie! I wouldn't put seventy-five cents into this broken-down rat trap!
answer: It's our home, Jim. Betsy was practically born in this apartment.

question: That does not make it a national shrine! Seven thousand dollars and not one word about closets.
answer: Closets! You wouldn't even let him get to the bathroom!

question: I haven't got that kind of money!
answer: The way you talk, Jim Blandings, you'd think I was some kind of congenital idiot!

question: Sometimes I'm beginning to wonder!
answer: You can just get out of here!

question: That's not a bad idea! Sorry.
answer: Good morning, Mr. Blandings.

question: 'Morning.
answer: You wanted to see the color copy from this month's House and Stream.

question: Hm?
answer: Will that be all?

question: Well, that's the way it all started. The ad was enough to convince Jim -- -- But Muriel was a little tougher. I guess the corsage did it.
answer: Jim, Muriel and Mr. Smith - They are driving through a beautiful Connecticut countryside. Mr. Smith, a local real estate dealer, is of that shrewd Yankee breed which specializes in the understatement, underselling school of salesmanship.

question: There they are, two little fish from New York -- out in the deep deep waters of Connecticut real estate. That's Smith, the real estate salesman. Mighty shrewd cookie in a quiet sort of way. Never thought he'd get a bite this quick. Now he's sizing up the catch. "Mm. Let's see. Convertible -- orchids -- must be pretty well fixed. Wonder if they're lookers or buyers?" They're buyers. Yes, sir, Smith, looks like you're finally going to unload the old Hackett place. Now first thing is get 'em a little anxious. Th-a-a-t's right!
answer: Jim, Muriel, Mr. Smith - They pass another house. Jim and Muriel appraise it with interest, look at Smith.

question: Uh-uh, not yet.
answer: Jim, Muriel and Mr. Smith - Another house.

question: Take it easy, Smith, give 'em a little more line.
answer: Jim, Muriel and Mr. Smith - The car pulls to a stop.

question: Of course, you understand, Mr. Smith, we're just window shopping, so to speak. Nothing really definite in mind.
answer: Perfectly all right.

question: Mm. Not a bad-looking place, but it's certainly a lot older than anything we had in mind.
answer: She's no spring chicken -- -- but that's just what makes her such a buy. This isn't just old timber, or a virgin stand oak grove other side of the trout stream, or a couple of fruit orchards... You're buying a piece of American history.

question: You don't say! How's that?
answer: First year she was built, General Gates stopped right here to water his horses.

question: Oh! Old General Gates -- Civil War.
answer: Revolutionary War.

question: Well -- I -- suppose as long as we're here...
answer: I guess it doesn't hurt to take a look.

question: It does have possibilities. Do you think we can get it?
answer: Like taking candy from a baby.

question: Now don't lose your head.
answer: Shh. Just keep quiet and let me handle this. Tell me, Smith, what kind of a price is the owner asking for this old place?

question: It's wonderful, Jim! That master bedroom with those two closets!
answer: Shh!

question: Funkhauser could do wonders with this --
answer: Funkhauser will have nothing to do with this house! Shh!

question: Ain't for sale!
answer: Why don't you folks just go out in back and take a look at the orchard?

question: How'm I doin', George?
answer: Nice timin', Eph. Think we got something here.

question: They the same people you showed it to in nineteen-thirty-eight?
answer: They were lookers -- this is the real thing.

question: If they got five thousand dollars on 'em. don't let 'em get away.
answer: They already offered ten.

question: Y'don't say... What's my asking price?
answer: Fifteen...

question: A mite stiff...
answer: I've got 'em measured. They're gonna take the place for -- eleven thousand.

question: Make it eleven thousand five hundred fifty.
answer: Odd kind of figure.

question: "Home, home in Connecticut With a closet to hang up your petticut..."
answer: ...Jim?

question: "No hustle or fuss No Fifth Avenue bus --"
answer: Uh -- Jim?

question: Hm?
answer: I was just wondering, dear. Ten thousand dollars is such an awful lot to offer -- That is, for two people who don't know anything at all about real estate, or anything... I mean, don't you think perhaps we should have asked someone's professional advice?

question: Like... say... a lawyer?
answer: Well, Bill knows about these things and --

question: Muriel, for once in my life I'm going to make one small decision, on my own, without the legalistic machinations of Mr. Bill Cole.
answer: It seems very peculiar that when your very best friend happens to be one of the very cleverest young lawyers in New York City --

question: Well?
answer: Miss Stellwagon says the current craze for modernizing old farmhouses is a form of totem worship.

question: Did it ever occur to you two that there may be some remote, intangible subjects upon which your Miss Irma Stellwagon is not the final authority?
answer: Why don't we buy a Solaxion house?

question: ...You know it's just barely conceivable -- What kind of a house?
answer: Solaxion. It's built on a mast like a tent and it revolves with the sun.

question: Oh, it... revolves... with the sun?
answer: That's right.

question: Who lives next door -- Buck Rogers?!
answer: It's the only practical way to live. When a new model comes out you trade the old one in like a used car.

question: From Smith! Mm.
answer: Well?

question: "I have conveyed your offer of ten thousand dollars to Mr. Hackett and am sorry to say he is not interested. However, I feel..."
answer: Oh, dear. Maybe we should have gone a few dollars higher.

question: What do you think, Bill? Steal, huh?
answer: It certainly is. Perhaps "steal" is an understatement -- "swindle" might be a little more appropriate.

question: Well, it wasn't much, Bill. I just saw a good thing and I -- What do you mean?
answer: Every time you get a little tight you weep on my shoulder about the advertising business and how it forces a sensitive soul like yourself to make a living by bamboozling the American public. I would say that a small part of this victimized group has now redressed the balance.

question: What are you talking about?
answer: You! You've been taken to the cleaners and you don't even know your pants are off!

question: All right, so it's thirty-five! What's the difference? Do you know how many tennis courts you can get on thirty- five acres?
answer: You're not spending eleven thousand five hundred dollars for tennis courts!

question: That's not the point!
answer: That's precisely the point. We're going to write this Hackett a strong letter and tell him he can either kick in with those fifteen acres, reduce the price, or find another sucker.

question: Now wait a minute! You can't measure everything on a slide rule. This house has certain intangibles.
answer: Like what, for instance?

question: Like antique value, for instance! It just so happens that General Gates stopped right there, at that very house, to water his horses.
answer: I don't care if General Grant dropped in for a scotch and soda -- you're still getting rocked!

question: They are probably mills that have shrunk.
answer: Well, you certainly aren't much of a help.

question: Look -- you really want to find that house of yours -- it's no problem. Just pretend you're one of General Gates' horses and you're thirsty... Now where would you go for a drink of water? Well, I must admit it's a very beautiful thing.
answer: The house and the lilac are just the same age, Bill; if the lilac can live and be so old, so can the house. It just needs someone to love it, that's all.

question: It's a good thing there are two of you -- one to love it and one to hold it up. What'd your engineer say when he checked over the foundation and that roof?
answer: Who needs engineers? This isn't a train, you know.

question: I just saw it move.
answer: This house has been standing since the second year of the Continental Congress. You take one look at it and shingles start to fall off!

question: Look -- let me do you a favor. I've got a client, crackerjack structural engineer, Joe Apollonio; he practically built the George Washington Bridge single-handed.
answer: Thanks a lot, but we're not building a bridge.

question: He's the follow who advised the Government not to raise the Normandie -- they didn't listen to him, cost them five million dollars.
answer: You have my word, if I were raising the Normandie, I wouldn't make a move without Apollonio. Now would you like to come inside and look around?

question: Uh-huh.
answer: Well, uh, what's your professional opinion?

question: Tear it down.
answer: Tear it down??!

question: If your chimney was shot and your sills was okay, I'd say go ahead, fix her up. If your sills was shot and your chimney was okay, again I'd say go ahead, fix her up. But your sills are shot and your chimney is shot. Take a look at the way she sags. So I say don't throw good money after bad -- tear it down.
answer: Thanks a lot.

question: It's okay.
answer: Bill Cole and his experts!

question: And -- uh -- have you any notions about how you'd like the old place taken down?
answer: Why don't we just blow on it?

question: There's a good local house wrecker. I'll have him contact you.
answer: Fine. You just shoot ahead with those plans, and remember, try to keep it down to ten, ten-five.

question: Well -- we'll try.
answer: There's one good thing about getting that old relic down. Those original beams and everything -- this time somebody pays us.

question: That's right, dear, cubage.
answer: What's that?

question: Oh -- just a figure of speech.
answer: But what does it mean?

question: Cubage. It's just the number of cubic feet that -- -- go into a cubic foot. Go on, Simms.
answer: Now is it absolutely essential for each of your daughters to have her own room with two closets and a separate bath?

question: Yes. You see, er, my daughters are, er, approaching womanhood, and, er --
answer: I hadn't realized they were approaching it quite so fast. Perhaps what you need is not so much a house as a series of little bungalows.

question: Hmmm. What about that silly flower sink? We could eliminate that.
answer: I beg your pardon.

question: Or that sewing room upstairs, that's certainly a waste.
answer: If we're going to eliminate anything, we'll lose that ridiculous play room in the basement with that great big poker table.

question: Honey, I've got to have some relaxation.
answer: We've got thirty-one and a half acres. Go out in the back and do a little gardening.

question: Prutty. Mrs. Bildad Prutty. Get a load of this! "The semi-monthly meeting of the Lansdale Historical Society was turned into an uproar last night when its president, Mrs. Bildad Prutty" -- How do you like that, Bildad Prutty? -- "reported the total demolition by its New York buyer of the historic old Hackett house." Bildad Prutty! Muriel, I've got to send this to the New Yorker!
answer: Read on, father.

question: "Mrs. Prutty," -- Bildad, that is -- "reminded her audience that several years ago the Society started to raise a fund to purchase and restore the old house to its original condition."
answer: Read on, father.

question: "The project fell through by being seven hundred dollars short of the sum of twenty-six hundred dollars..." "...which Ephemus Hackett testified was the lowest reasonable price he could accept as --" ...Twenty-six hundred dollars.
answer: And what did we pay, father?

question: I quite agree. But you're dealing with a man who doesn't think before he acts, who goes off half-cocked!
answer: What is it? What did I do?

question: You're an architect! You must have been aware of the legality involved.
answer: What? What legality?

question: Bill, I've had a very trying day. Would you mind telling me in clear, concise English just what crime I've committed -- and why?!
answer: In clear, concise English, you tore down a house on which another man holds a mortgage without first getting his written permission.

question: Well, I -- I did?!
answer: And in such case, the mortgagee can demand the full payment of said mortgage upon demand -- and Mr. Ephemus Hackett so demands! Six thousand clams! And he wants them now!

question: Now?!
answer: You've got ten days.

question: I don't know, turn in my insurance policies or something.
answer: Now, Jim, you can't do that.

question: Why not?
answer: What if something should happen? You can't leave the children unprotected.

question: I'm not dead yet! And if I die, there's plenty left to take care of them.
answer: Not if you cash in your policies.

question: Good night, Bill. What a wonderful friend.
answer: What's with this kissing all of a sudden?

question: What's that?
answer: Just because a man is helpful in a business way, it doesn't give him extra-curricular privileges with my wife!

question: That's a fine thing to say about a friend of fifteen years!
answer: Well, I don't like it. Every time he goes out of this house, he shakes my hand and he kisses you.

question: Would you prefer it the other way around?!
answer: Well, I don't like it, that's all! Why is he always hanging around? Why doesn't he ever get married -- or something?

question: Because he can't find another girl as sweet and pretty and wholesome as I am.
answer: Well -- it -- it doesn't look right. There are limits to friendship and --

question: Darling, let's not be silly about this. It's not Bill, it's the house you're upset about.
answer: I suppose so. Do you think it's worth all this?

question: Of course, darling. We're not just building a house -- it's a home. A home for ourselves -- and our children -- and maybe our children's children.
answer: It's getting awfully crowded with only three bathrooms.

question: Now obviously these bids are way out of line, that is, all except John Retch and Son at twenty-one thousand.
answer: Twenty-one thousand!

question: And with some judicious cutting, I think we can pare that down to eighteen.
answer: We've only asked for the barest necessities --

question: Well, things are certainly humming.
answer: What's that?

question: I said, humming.
answer: Oh. What's going on over there?

question: That's Mr. Tesander. He's digging our well.
answer: Well? What happened to the trout stream, with that pure, clear, cold mountain water?

question: What's the matter, Mr. Zucca? Something wrong?
answer: How do you lika that? Broka my bucket. Two times this week I broka my bucket?

question: What did you do, strike a boulder?
answer: Atsa no boulder, atsa ledge.

question: What does that mean?
answer: Meansa we gotta blast!

question: Blast?
answer: Blast. Witha dynamite.

question: But you don't gotta worry. Only cost twenty-four cents a cubic foot, plussa dynamite an'a fuse.
answer: But how far will you have to blast?

question: Harda tell. Might be a lilla baby ledge -- mighta run the whole toppa the mountain.
answer: At twenty-four cents a foot? Do you realize what that means?!

question: Meansa we gotta blast.
answer: Well, anyway, our house will never sink.

question: I think I'd better have a little talk with Mr. Tesander. Oh -- Mr. Tesander -- Mr. Tesander!
answer: Yep?

question: How's it coming?
answer: It's comin'.

question: No -- no -- I mean -- Mr. Tesander!
answer: Yep?

question: What I meant was -- how far down are you?
answer: Oh -- 'bout a hundred and ninety feet.

question: Well -- isn't that pretty deep?
answer: Yep.

question: Do you think maybe you'd better try another spot?
answer: Up to you.

question: I mean -- well, have you hit anything yet at all?
answer: Hit some limestone yesterday.

question: Is that good?
answer: That's bad. And right now it looks like we're coming into some shale.

question: That's bad?
answer: That's good.

question: Oh...
answer: 'Course it might turn out to be sandstone.

question: That's bad? That's good?
answer: Can't tell. Might be good. Might be bad. One thing you know -- you got plenty of shale, sandstone and limestone.

question: And just what does that mean?
answer: Meansa we gotta blast.

question: You see, Mary, the average fellow who builds a house doesn't know where he stands from day to day -- but I do things a little differently. With a few minor deviations I know exactly where every penny is going --
answer: Hi.

question: Bill! Come in, come in.
answer: Just going over the Knapp contracts with old man Dascomb and I -- uh -- Can I talk?

question: Sure. What's up?
answer: While I was in there with Dascomb the conversation kind of got around to you and -- uh --

question: What is it?
answer: Well, he didn't say in so many words that ever since you started with that house you haven't turned in a decent piece of copy, but --

question: But you kind of got the feeling...
answer: ...that if I told you, you'd know that he knew that you knew that he knew... that you knew... or something.

question: Huh? What's that? What do you mean we've got two wells? I'll be right out. Come on, Bill, we'd better get out to Lansdale.
answer: Anything wrong?

question: Mary, have you ever seriously considered building a house?
answer: Well, no offense, Mr. Blandings, but my boy friend says that anybody who builds a house today is crazy.

question: Tsk, tsk, tsk.
answer: Water, Mr. Tesander.

question: Yep.
answer: At six feet!

question: Yep.
answer: And over there, just thirty-two yards away, you had to go down two hundred and twenty-seven feet to hit the same water.

question: Yep.
answer: How do you account for that, Mr. Tesander?

question: On them second floor lintels between the lally columns, do you want we should rabbet them or not?
answer: The -- second -- floor -- lallys?

question: The second floor lintels, between the lallys.
answer: Oh. Oh, the lintels between the lallys?

question: Yeah. From the blueprints you can't tell. You want they should be rabbeted?
answer: Un -- umm. No, I guess not.

question: Okay, you're the doctor. Hey, fellas, you got any of them rabbeted lintels set, rip 'em out!
answer: It sounded less... expensive to say no.

question: Now look what you've done. Look, men, Mrs. Blandings didn't mean anything. I mean, there's no point in walking off a job just because... a woman makes a silly little remark.
answer: I'm just sick. From the outside this house looks like a grain elevator, and on the inside everything's miles too small. What's that?

question: What's what?
answer: That noise -- listen. It's coming from the closet!

question: What happened?
answer: The door blew shut. I got locked in.

question: Impossible. I had this closet built especially for myself. The lock opens from the inside.
answer: Maybe for Houdini -- not for me.

question: Nothing to it. A child could work it. Look, I'll show you. You see, it just takes a little good old Yankee know-how.
answer: You know, dear, it's just possible the lock worked for you and not for Bill.

question: Ridiculous. Even you could do it.
answer: Thank you.

question: Never mind, Betsy. Dear, I'm going up to the place this afternoon to see about landscaping. Bill's driving me.
answer: That's nice. What do you mean, Bill's driving you?

question: Why do you always say, "what do you mean," when you know perfectly well what I mean and what you mean?
answer: I mean that every time I turn my back Bill Cole's driving you some place or something.

question: He's only being helpful.
answer: I thought he was a lawyer! Why isn't he out suing somebody?

question: We'll just see about that!
answer: What is it, dear? Jim, what's the matter?

question: Mr. William Cole, please. Hello, Bill? I want you to fight this thing! I know my rights as a citizen! They can't get away with it!... What do you mean, what am I talking about? The letter, of course. From the owner of this building. They want us to move! It's a thirty day notice! But that's ridiculous. How can I move into a house that isn't even finished?! No windows, no plaster -- or paint, or -- or plumbing! Now you listen to me! I have no intention of moving in thirty days! This is not legal! I'm going to fight this thing! And I don't care if it takes every penny I've got! Yeah... Yeah... Yeah... All right!
answer: ...Well?

question: Where's Simms? What's the problem? You put windows up. Oh, they don't, don't they? What's this about the windows?
answer: I'm afraid there's a little slip-up. These windows seem to belong to a Mr. Landings in Fishkill, New York. I talked to Mr. Landings this morning.

question: Well, has he got mine?
answer: No, he seems to have some windows that belong to a Mr. Blandsworth of Peekskill.

question: Where are my windows?!
answer: As near as we can figure out they've either been sent to a Mr. Benton in Evanston, Illinois, or a Mr. Bamberger of Phoenix, Arizona.

question: What are we supposed to do -- live the rest of our lives in a house without windows?
answer: It'll just be a matter of a few days.

question: Now I want the living room to be a soft green. Not quite as bluish as a robin's egg, but yet not as yellow as daffodil buds.
answer: Mm.

question: The best sample I could get is a little too yellow, but don't let whoever mixes it go to the other extreme and get it too blue. It should just be sort of a grayish yellow green.
answer: Mm-hmm.

question: Now the dining room I'd like yellow. Not just yellow, a very gay yellow.
answer: Mm-hmm.

question: Something bright and sunshiny. I tell you, Mr. PeDelford, if you'll just send one of your workmen to the A&P for a pound of their best butter and match it exactly, you can't go wrong.
answer: Mm.

question: This is the paper we're going to use here in the foyer. It's flowered but I don't want the ceiling to match any of the colors of the flowers. There are some little dots in the background, and it's these dots I want you to match. Not the little greenish dots near the hollyhock leaf, but the little bluish dot between the rosebud and the delphinium blossom. Is that clear?
answer: Mm-hmm.

question: The kitchen's to be white. Not a cold, antiseptic hospital white -- a little warmer but not to suggest any other color but white.
answer: Mm.

question: Now for the powder room, I want you to match this thread. You can see it's practically an apple red. Somewhere between a healthy Winesap and an unripened Jonathan.
answer: Mm.

question: Will you excuse me?
answer: Got it, Charlie? Check.

question: Not till the Commuter's Special tomorrow morning at six-fifteen.
answer: You mean seven-fifteen.

question: No, Dad, six-fifteen.
answer: What about the seven-fifteen I'm supposed to take to the office every morning?!

question: There's a little asterisk. The seven- fifteen only runs Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.
answer: Let me see that! Muriel!

question: Let me see that! Muriel!
answer: Oh, dear, don't tell me I read it wrong.

question: That's fine! For the rest of my life I'm going to have to get up at five o'clock in the morning to catch the six-fifteen, to get to my office by eight, which doesn't even open until nine -- and which I never get to until ten!
answer: Perhaps if you started earlier you could quit earlier.

question: I'll scout around and find you a place in Lansdale. Now, you're not going to change your mind about coming up?
answer: Don't worry, I'll be on the job.

question: It won't be easy. I promise you a Cook's tour of every lamp maker, rug weaver, and antique shop in Lansdale County.
answer: When I married you two I suppose I took you for better or for worse.

question: Good old Uncle Bill.
answer: Good old Uncle Bill.

question: Next time we want a fire I'll send out for a three-year-old child! Get that stuff cleaned up and go in and help Gussie set the table. It's getting late.
answer: Look, Dad, your fraternity pins.

question: Pins? I only had one.
answer: There are two of them here.

question: All right, all right. Just put them away.
answer: Funny, this one says W.C. on the back. W.C.? William Cole! It must be Uncle Bill's!

question: Huh? Let me see that. Hmmmm.
answer: What's that?

question: That's none of your business!
answer: I'd say mother and Uncle Bill were somewhat of an item!

question: People do not read other people's diaries! It's not a very nice thing to do! Now go in there and help Gussie with the table.
answer: What about --?

question: I'll take care of that. Now, shoo, shoo.
answer: Where are you going?

question: To shave.
answer: Tonight??

question: While I can still trust myself with a razor. At six o'clock in the morning I'd probably cut my throat. Goodnight.
answer: Excuse... Excuse...

question: Muriel, do you have to do that now?!
answer: There's no need to be so irritable just because you have to shave at night.

question: I'm not irritable!
answer: Well, you're certainly something! You haven't said a civil word all evening.

question: Sometimes a man doesn't feel like talking.
answer: What is it, dear? Something down at the office?

question: No.
answer: Have you got the new slogan for "Wham"?

question: It's not due yet!
answer: Well, it's something. You're certainly upset about something. I can always tell.

question: I'm not upset. It's just that I don't happen to approve of falsehood and deception. Particularly in my own wife.
answer: What are you talking about?

question: Oh, nothing. It's just that I distinctly remember your telling me you gave back Bill's fraternity pin fifteen years ago. Well, did you or didn't you?
answer: Did I, or didn't I what?

question: Give it back to him.
answer: Of course I did. If I said I did, I did.

question: Then perhaps you'd have the goodness to explain how this happened to fall out of your jewel box? What's so funny?
answer: You! You're jealous! You're standing there with your face full of soap and you're jealous.

question: If you were so crazy about the guy, why didn't you marry him?!
answer: Because I wasn't in love with him!

question: That's not what you said in your diary!
answer: Oh, now you've been reading my diary!

question: Well -- it happened to fall open and... I... happened to look at it. It... just happened.
answer: I'll just bet!

question: It's all over the book so why don't you admit it? You were in love with Bill Cole!
answer: Don't be absurd! Of course I was in love with Bill. In those days I was in love with a new man every week.

question: Then why did you marry me?
answer: I'm beginning to wonder! Maybe it was those big cow eyes of yours or that ridiculous hole in your chin! Maybe I knew that some day you'd bring me out to this thirty- eight thousand dollar icebox with a dried-up trout stream and no windows! Or maybe I just happened to fall in love with you -- but for heaven's sake, don't ask me why!

question: ...Muriel? ...Honey? Would it do any good to say I'm sorry?
answer: I don't know.

question: Well -- I am. I acted like a schoolboy and I'm sorry.
answer: Oh, Jim! Why don't you take the soap out of your ears?

question: Why do I love you so much?
answer: Darling, it's awfully late. Maybe you ought to go down and lock the doors.

question: What for? The windows are all open anyway.
answer: Jim, you have to get up at six o'clock.

question: Yes, I guess so.
answer: Goodnight, dear.

question: You'd better send out for coffee and sandwiches,... It looks like an all night session.
answer: What did he say?

question: Tomorrow morning.
answer: Well, I guess you'll just have to dream something up -- good or bad.

question: I rather got the impression it had better be good.
answer: Oh.

question: Thank heavens! The children.
answer: Stay put. You look too comfortable. Oh, I'm not Mr. Blandings. Cole's the name, Bill Cole. Friend of the family. Wet clothes. Just came in out of the rain.

question: I'm Mrs. Blandings. Thank you. I was beginning to get concerned. Can I make you a cup of tea?
answer: Cole. Bill Cole. Friend of the family. Just came in out of the rain.

question: Goodnight... and thanks so much.
answer: That's fine. No bridge. How do I get back to Lansdale?

question: You'll just have to spend the night right here.
answer: Muriel, really! With your husband in New York and your children away -- think of my reputation.

question: Don't worry, Snow White, you'll be as pure and unsullied in the morning as you were the night before.
answer: That's the story of my life.

question: Poor Jim, he sounded so worried before. I certainly hope he comes up with something.
answer: Don't worry about the man who gave the world "When you've got the whim, say Wham!"-- This well will never run dry.

question: "Compare the price, compare the slice, Take our advice -- Buy Wham!" "If you'd buy better ham. You'd better buy Wham!"
answer: It's Boyle Petroleum. "If you'd buy better oil, You'd better buy Boyle."

question: "This little pig went to market As meek and as mild as a lamb. He smiled in his tracks When they slipped him the axe He knew he'd turn out to be Wham!" "...knew he'd turn out to be Wham!" It's gone! I've lost my touch! Maybe I never had a touch! Maybe "Whim Say Wham" was an accident! Who knows? I can't think any more! All I've got on my mind is a house with an eighteen thousand dollar mortgage, and bills, and extras, and antiques, and -- and -- I don't know... I don't know.
answer: Where are you going?

question: Home, to get some sleep -- and I'd advise you to do the same.
answer: But -- but you haven't --

question: Suppose I haven't! This isn't the only job in town!
answer: But -- but -- what'll I tell Mr. Dascomb?

question: You just tell him to -- to -- You just tell him! 'Morning, dear.
answer: Darling, you must be exhausted. How did it go?

question: Fine. Fine.
answer: Is... everything all right?

question: Everything's fine. Hello, Simms, what brings you out with the morning dew?
answer: Just dropped by to check the blueprints. Some extras came in from Retch this morning and there're a couple of things I thought we ought to go over together.

question: Really. What are they?
answer: Well, let's see. Few little things here, all right, I guess. "Mortising five butts -- a dollar sixty-eight."

question: Let's not quibble about that. A man's entitled to mortise a few butts now and then.
answer: Extra nails and screws -- three dollars, eighty-nine cents.

question: Petty larceny, but let him get away with it.
answer: Now there's one here I frankly don't understand. Ah, here we are. "Changes in closet, twelve hundred and forty-seven dollars." Did you authorize that?

question: Well, we probably told him to -- Twelve hundred and what?!
answer: Forty-seven dollars. Changes in closet.

question: Who does he think we are! What's this notation
answer: Far as I remember, that would be something in the back of the house. Let's just take a look. Ah, here we are. It isn't a closet at all. It's off the back pantry... Mrs. Blandings' little flower sink.

question: Oh... Mrs. Blandings' little flower sink.
answer: You didn't authorize any changes, did you?

question: Well... they certainly weren't changes.
answer: What -- have -- you -- done?

question: I haven't done anything! And what I did was... just nothing at all.
answer: What -- have -- you -- done?!

question: Well -- All I did was one day I saw four pieces of flagstone left over from the porch that were just going to be thrown away because nobody wanted them and I asked Mr. Retch if he wouldn't just put them down on the floor of the flower sink and poke a little cement between the cracks and give me a nice stone floor where it might be wet with flowers and things. That was absolutely all I did.
answer: That's all you did?

question: 'Morning, everybody. Whew! What a night!
answer: Where have you been?

question: Lansdale. Couldn't get back across the bridge.
answer: You... weren't here last night?

question: Just a minute. You mean the children weren't here last night either?
answer: How could they be, dear? The bridge was closed.

question: I just came across it.
answer: Well, it was closed last night.

question: Well, that's about the size of it -- -- except that Retch had to repair the pantry wall and that meant getting a plasterer back. And of course, he couldn't have broken through that wall --
answer: All right, Simms, all right. We'll take care of it.

question: I'll admit it's a little steep. But I'll try to get Retch to knock a hundred dollars off the bill. If I can't get that, I'll certainly try for seventy-five.
answer: Fine.

question: If he doesn't go for seventy-five, I'll take a stab at fifty.
answer: You do that.

question: Now dear, you're upset, you've got a lot of things on your mind --
answer: Muriel, there's only one thing on my mind -- This house -- and how fast we can get rid of it!

question: That's not what you're thinking.
answer: Maybe it's not. Maybe I'm thinking I was once a happy man! I didn't have a closet, I didn't have three bathrooms, but I did have my sanity, a few dollars in the bank, two children who loved me and a wife I could trust!

question: That's a fine thing to say!
answer: I also had a job at Danton and Bascomb, something I don't happen to have at the moment!

question: Jim!
answer: That's right, I've resigned! We're starting all over again! From scratch! And without this house!

question: You love this house!
answer: I hate it!

question: You don't mean that.
answer: Every word of it! Anybody who builds a house today is crazy! The minute you start, they put you on the list. The All-American Sucker list! Everywhere you turn they've got a hand in your pocket. If you take out their hands, they find more pockets! It's a conspiracy, I tell you, a conspiracy against every man and woman who want a home of their own! Against every boy and girl who were ever in love! What do you want?!

question: Every word of it! Anybody who builds a house today is crazy! The minute you start, they put you on the list. The All-American Sucker list! Everywhere you turn they've got a hand in your pocket. If you take out their hands, they find more pockets! It's a conspiracy, I tell you, a conspiracy against every man and woman who want a home of their own! Against every boy and girl who were ever in love! What do you want?!
answer: Well, Mr. Blandings, there's a matter of twelve dollars and eighty-six cents.

question: Twelve dollars and eighty-six cents! Why be a piker, Mr. Tesander? Take everything I've got! Spread it out among your pals! Wouldn't Retch like a little something? Maybe Zucca could use my new dinner jacket? It's open house, Mr. Tesander! Help yourself! If this isn't enough I'll come over to your place and do some odd chores. Maybe I can mow your lawn or scratch your back!
answer: You don't understand, Mr. Blandings. This twelve dollars and eighty-six cents -- you don't owe me, I owe you.

question: ...W-what was that?
answer: Found I overcharged you. Almost three feet. Better count it. I think it's all there.
